Schematic, Generic.text: Run ERC, ensure all errors are accounted for
Schematic, Generic.info: While the ERC I personally don't find that useful, they can potentially catch unwanted errors

Schematic, Generic.text: Ensure title block is somewhat correct
Schematic, Generic.info: While not as needed for a personal project, I think at least some title and a revision at minimum should be entered

Schematic, Generic.text: Ensure a nominal passive voltage/power/tolerances spec are listed
Schematic, Generic.info: This is to ensure that nominal capacitor voltages and resistor tolerances required for the design are stated. For example a digital circuit may only need 16v caps, while something else might require 25v caps nominally

Schematic, Generic.text: Check that all passives with non-nominal rating (especially capacitor voltage) is explicitly called out
Schematic, Generic.info: This is so non-nominal capacitors (for example a 100v capacitor for POE) is explicitly called out, as the rest of the design could use 25v rated caps

Schematic, Generic.text: Check pinout of any previously unused symbol against datasheet
Schematic, Generic.info: It's not a bad idea to double check in case the library creator got it wrong. It will be a pain to debug if two pins are swapped for example

Schematic, Generic.text: Ensure footprint of symbols are set to maximal pad size if pcb space allows for hand-solderability
Schematic, Generic.info: To make passives hand solderable if space on the board allows. In KiCAD these are generally the footprint labeled with 'HandSolderable'. This is here as it's in the schematic that the footprints are decided

Schematic, Generic.text: Inverted signals should be indicated (bar on top or _N suffix)
Schematic, Generic.info: To indicate to the reader which net labels are functionally inverted

Schematic, Digital.text: Check that a microcontroller's pin functions is allowed on that pin, either fixed function per pin or an internal mux
Schematic, Digital.info: For example if SDA is allowed on PC6 on at ATMega328P. Some MCUs, like PIC32, have a PPS mux thing that doesn't allow any pin to connect to any peripheral, so it's impervious that is checked

Schematic, Digital.text: Double check I2C and SPI connections (SDA vs SCL for example)
Triple check UART directionality, or add poka-yoke

PCB, Generic.text: Check design rule check matches manufacturer tolerances, if different than default
Run DRC, ensure no unexpected errors
Ensure copper pours have no neck-downs
Ensure copper pours are tied to a net
Check footprint (especially self-made) of any previously unused footprint against datasheet

PCB, Silkscreen.text: Check that reference designators are close to their component
Check for pcb part number and revision on silkscreen
Check that silkscreen text is visible and not obscured by components in 3D viewer, if possible
Check that silkscreen on bottom side of the board are inverted

PCB, Silkscreen.info: Silksreeen is free, might as well go nuts

PCB, Mechanical.text: Check that the board with components fits inside the enclosure, including mounting hole size (if already designed or fixed)
Check for screw head clearance, and mark outline in silkscreen if room allows

PCB, High Voltage.text: Ensure adequate clearance and creepage around high voltage traces
For any area of the board with >50v, add a high voltage warning on the silkscreen

PCB, Feedback Resistors.text: Check that high impedance paths, such as those feedback resistors in an op-amp circuit, are close to the component
PCB, Feedback Resistors.info: High impedance line running across the board is just asking for coupling of any E-fields

Gerbers.text: Quickly go through generated gerber files and individually check each layer
Gerbers.info: Sometimes, in my experience, some things are only caught in this functional check, for example not noticing an incorrect solder mask
